Posts.Content: Hi there and welcome to Inspire. Sorry you have the need to join but I have found it a useful site. I’m in between Glasgow and Stirling, where are you? I’ll write again as kids just down and pile of ironing to do but I tend to look on here most nights. I’ve been metastatic for two half years. I’m her2 and hormone positive,deducing you are hormone positive? I get where you are coming from. My feeling is it’s probably from your hormone drugs, i’m only on zoladex but at times i feel miserable on it. No oomph yet physically keep quite well on kadcyla, though i do notice on weekends like this when i had it on Friday and have had the kids to entertain all weekend (hubby is on nights) i’m tired and easily stressed. I imagine if i’d felt like this as result of a natural menopause I would have been to the GP asking for HRT!. I’m 49, so not many friends at this stage yet. Anyway you will read from some very inspiring, knowledgeable and uplifting people on this site so I hope it’s useful to dip into and as i say I’m happy to chat with you anon. Anne
Posts.Title: Depression and breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Beth, that seems a pretty high dose for anti emetic purposes over a period of days. I can’t exactly remember dose i took for lymphoma chemo but i definitely relate to feeling “wired” then. Now for MBC I’m on Kadcyla but have luckily never needed pre chemo anti emetic cover so yes you can do it without the dex. I only occasionally need a little metoclopramide so i’m lucky. Could they look at increasing your zofran dose instead. Must be some new anti emetics out there now, all these drugs were around when i worked in oncology 20 years ago! Hope you get something better to suit and that Kadcyla is beneficial for you once again Anne x
Posts.Title: Dexamethasone and chemo
